description: Move you camera until white dots will display in your screen. Touch at any white dots to start your learning!
Welcome, class! Today, we're setting the stage for an incredible performance the
drama of the ecosystem!  An ecosystem is a complex community of living organisms
(biotic) interacting with their non-living (abiotic) environment.  Let's break down
these key players and see how they work together!
Imagine a bustling city full of people, animals, and plants.  These are all biotic
components of an ecosystem.  They are the living organisms that interact with each
other and their environment:
Producers: These are the life-starters, like plants and algae. They capture energy
from the sun through photosynthesis and use it to produce food (sugar) for
themselves and other organisms. Think of them as the ecosystem's chefs, cooking
up the foundation of the food chain.
Consumers: These are the hungry bunch! They rely on producers for energy. There are different types of consumers:
Herbivores: These plant-eaters, like rabbits and deer, munch on producers.
Carnivores: These meat-eaters, like lions and wolves, consume other animals.
Omnivores: These flexible feeders, like humans and bears, eat both plants and animals.
Decomposers: These are nature's clean-up crew, like bacteria and fungi. They
break down dead organisms and waste products, returning nutrients to the
ecosystem. Think of them as the recyclers, keeping the system running smoothly.
Now, imagine the city without its buildings, water supply, or sunlight.  These are the
abiotic components of an ecosystem.  They are the non-living physical and chemical
factors that influence living organisms: Physical Factors: These include things like:
Climate: Temperature, precipitation (rain and snow), and sunlight all play a crucial role in an ecosystem.
Water: This is essential for all living things.
Soil: This provides nutrients and support for plants and other organisms that live in or on it.
Gases: Oxygen is vital for most living things, while carbon dioxide is used by plants for photosynthesis.
The real magic happens when biotic and abiotic components interact! Here is the example
Plants need sunlight (abiotic) for photosynthesis and water (abiotic) to grow.
In turn, they provide food and oxygen (biotic) for animals (biotic).
That's all class! Good job!
